newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stock index falls below key 1,000 level.
newsitem.headline: Thai stock index falls below key 1,000 level.

text.p: Thai stocks fell by 2.27 percent with the index sliding below the key psychologically-important 1,000-point level and a 35-month-low on Friday amid forced selling, brokers said.
The index fell 23.24 points to 999.44 at 0350 GMT and continued falling, briefly hitting an intrad-day low of 995.79.
Some investors, mainly locals, were being forced to sell shares if they could not top up theeir margin loans, brokers said. Tghis had forced weak sentiment and pushed prices down.
"Right now there is no positive news and there are no chances for the index to rebound," said one broker.
"The market fundamentals are now changed after the index fell below the psychologically-important 1,000-point," said the broker who asked not to be identified.
Brokers said there was no sign selling might stop at present.
The effects of the rumours that some brokerage firms may be hit by small-time investors without strong financial background to repay maintenance margin fees to the companies was strong, they added.
Officials at both the central bank and the stock market have denied the rumours.
"Local investors are being forced to sell shares as they didn't have enough money to pay for margin loans," said a broker at First Asia Securities.
Two Thai brokerages, Sitca Finance and Securities and First Asia and First City Investments clarified their financial positions were stable in the face of the market rumours.

Blue chip Thai Military Bank topped the active list, falling 2.50 baht to 73.50 while large capitalised Finance One declined 2.50 to 94.50. Another bank down Thai Farmers Bank which fell four baht to 162.
